awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding the Printability of Liquid Metal Dispersions for Additive Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant will investigate an additive manufacturing process using liquid metal. This work has the potential to enable a new class of stretchable electronic devices to serve as platforms for soft robotics, safe human-machine interaction, active orthotics, wearable interfaces, or assistive medical devices for motion aid, prolonged endurance, and health-monitoring. In this research program, stretchable composite materials with electronic functionality will be created by printing liquid-metal traces in elastic polymers. The composite materials are expected to retain the function of rigid metal conductors while leveraging the highly deformable properties of the plastic matrix. The work will focus on the fundamental problems surrounding the processing of liquid metal in order to develop a scalable manufacturing process. The educational and outreach activities include the development of a low-cost, accessible, and scalable soft robot designed for middle- and high-school students.

Additive manufacturing with liquid-metal dispersions will bridge the gap between well-established scalable liquid processing, such as printing, and the processing of emerging soft functional materials that exhibit high surface tension, viscosity, and density properties that typically preclude printability. The research objective of this project is to derive and validate the fundamental electromechanical behavior of liquid-metal dispersions during synthesis, deposition, and coalescence. The mechanical response of liquid-metal through these three processing phases will be coupled to its bulk electrical response using experiments, theories, and numerical models across different length scales. This grant will enable a fundamental understanding of the basic principles underlying scalable materials processing for soft electromechanical systems and will significantly improve our ability to design soft machines that deform, react to their environment, and adapt.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Soft electronic systems require flexible and stretchable conductors for applications in soft robotics, wearable technologies, and human-machine interfaces. Gallium-based room temperature liquid metals have emerged as promising candidates; However, the scalable processing of eutectic gallium-indium has remained a challenge due to its unique surface tension, viscosity, and density properties. This CAREER project investigated the emulsification of liquid metal into particles (or droplets) that, when suspended in a carrier solvent to create liquid metal dispersion inks, are compatible with scalable fabrication techniques. The overall aim of this project was to derive and validate the fundamental electromechanical behavior of these liquid metal dispersions during synthesis, deposition, and coalescence (sintering). We studied the electromechanical responses of liquid metal through these three processing phases using experiments, theories, and numerical models across different length scales.

During the project period, we completed three main tasks: (1) A parametric characterization of dispersion ink synthesis, where the objective was to understand how the ink composition and synthesis parameters affect the resulting physical properties of the gallium indium dispersions and their printability; (2) A surface characterization of deposited dispersion inks, where the objective was to understand the behavior of dispersion inks as they wet and dry on a substrate; and (3) A derivation of experimentally validated electromechanical models of directed coalescence, where coalescence was induced by particle surface oxide rupture due to loading or particle surface oxide removal due to reduction (ablation).

Significant results of this project include rigorous understandings of eutectic gallium-indium (eGaIn) particle sintering via mechanical, laser, and thermal means. Building on these understandings, we introduced a novel biphasic gallium-indium (bGaIn) formulation---resulting from thermal sintering of eGaIn particles---which exhibits strain-insensitive behavior and tunable rheology. We showed the compatibility of bGaIn with scalable fabrication methods, robust interfaces with off-the-shelf electronic components, and electrical/mechanical cyclic stability. Finally, we enabled the direct conversion of established circuit board assemblies to soft and stretchable forms.

This project also included a strong emphasis on education and outreach. We developed a foundational soft robot design activity that is cost-efficient, scalable and yields a high success rate to encourage further exploration of STEM disciplines. We implemented the design activity at least annually with middle- and high-school students, and each year we modified our implementation approaches and data collection instruments to refine the activity. 


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio
